As shown in Fig. 4A, deoxycholic acid and its conjugates GDA and taurodeoxycholic acid at concentrations of 1% solubilized the Leishmania microsomes efficiently. GDA was chosen for further usage because of its tolerance of high concentrations of salt. GDA solubilized the LPG2-HIS protein from Leishmania microsomes in amounts as low as 0.2% (Fig. 4B), but GDA was used for LPG2-HIS purification at a concentration of 0.5%, corresponding to 5-fold above its critical micelle concentration. To purify the GDA-solubilized LPG2-HIS, the extract was applied sequentially to two resins that interact with the His6 tag, and purification was monitored by SDS-PAGE followed by silver staining and anti-His tag Western

The alkylsulfatase AtsK from Pseudomonas putida S-313 is a member of the non-heme iron(II)-α-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenase superfamily. In the initial step of their catalytic cycle, enzymes belonging to this widespread and versatile family coordinate molecular oxygen to the iron center in the active site. The subsequent decarboxylation of the cosubstrate α-ketoglutarate yields carbon dioxide, succinate, and a highly reactive ferryl (IV) species, which is required for substrate oxidation via a complex mechanism involving the transfer of radical species. Non-productive activation of oxygen may lead to harmful side reactions; therefore, such enzymes need an effective built-in protection mechanism. One of the ways of controlling undesired side reactions is the self-hydroxylation of an aromatic side chain, which leads to an irreversibly inactivated species. Here we describe the crystal structure of the alkylsulfatase AtsK in complexes with succinate and with Fe(II)/succinate. In the crystal structure of the AtsK-Fe(II)-succinate complex, the side chain of Tyr168 is co-ordinated to the iron, suggesting that Tyr168 is the target of enzyme self-hydroxylation. This is the first structural study of an Fe(II)-α-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenase that presents an aromatic side chain coordinated to the metal center, thus allowing structural insight into this protective mechanism of enzyme self-inactivation. The alkylsulfatase AtsK from Pseudomonas putida S-313 is a member of the non-heme iron(II)-α-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenase superfamily. In the initial step of their catalytic cycle, enzymes belonging to this widespread and versatile family coordinate molecular oxygen to the iron center in the active site. The subsequent decarboxylation of the cosubstrate α-ketoglutarate yields carbon dioxide, succinate, and a highly reactive ferryl (IV) species, which is required for substrate oxidation via a complex mechanism involving the transfer of radical species. Non-productive activation of oxygen may lead to harmful side reactions; therefore, such enzymes need an effective built-in protection mechanism. One of the ways of controlling undesired side reactions is the self-hydroxylation of an aromatic side chain, which leads to an irreversibly inactivated species. Here we describe the crystal structure of the alkylsulfatase AtsK in complexes with succinate and with Fe(II)/succinate. In the crystal structure of the AtsK-Fe(II)-succinate complex, the side chain of Tyr168 is co-ordinated to the iron, suggesting that Tyr168 is the target of enzyme self-hydroxylation. This is the first structural study of an Fe(II)-α-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenase that presents an aromatic side chain coordinated to the metal center, thus allowing structural insight into this protective mechanism of enzyme self-inactivation. The alkylsulfatase AtsK from Pseudomonas putida S-313 is a member of the family of non-heme iron(II), α-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenases (1Kahnert A. Kertesz M.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 31661-31667Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar, 2Ryle M.J. Hausinger R.P. Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol. 2002; 6: 193-201Crossref PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar). This remarkable superfamily is widespread among prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms, and its members catalyze a broad diversity of energetically demanding biosynthetic and degradative reactions including hydroxylation processes, stereoselective desaturation of inactivated carbon-carbon single bonds, and oxidative ring closure (3Hausinger R.P. Crit. Rev. Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2004; 39: 1-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (739) Google Scholar). The catalytic mechanism of this enzyme superfamily has been the topic of numerous spectroscopic and structural investigations (Fig. 1). This family of enzymes all bind iron using a 2-His-1-carboxylate facial triad, a feature that is one of nature's recurring multifunctional bioinorganic motifs such as the heme group or iron-sulfur clusters. They catalyze the oxidative conversion of the cofactor αKG 1The abbreviations used are: αKG, α-ketoglutarate; TauD, taurine dioxygenase; EPR, electron paramagnetic resonance; PDB, Protein Data Bank. into CO2 and succinate, simultaneously generating an activated oxygen species bound to the oxidized Fe center. The generally accepted mechanism proceeds via a Fe(IV)-oxo intermediate (4Price J.C. Barr E.W. Glass T.E. Krebs C. Bollinger Jr., J.M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2003; 125: 13008-13009Crossref PubMed Scopus (335) Google Scholar). The interaction of this activated intermediate with the enzyme substrate generates a transient radical species that subsequently decomposes to the reaction product. A reaction mechanism that involves radical formation would at first sight seem to be a hazardous method for an organism to accomplish the relatively straightforward cleavage reaction that is catalyzed by AtsK (i.e. the release of sulfate from an alkyl sulfate ester), because harmful side reactions could take place in the absence of substrate. Such enzymes must therefore have an effective built-in protection mechanism, and indeed, several checks exist to control undesired side reactions. First, kinetic studies have shown that the oxygen activation process is much slower in the absence of substrate. In the case of the taurine dioxygenase (TauD), for example, stopped-flow kinetic analysis of the taurine-αKG·Fe(II)·TauD and the substrate-free Fe·αKG·TauD complexes have shown that the oxygen reactivity of the latter is orders of magnitude lower than that of the substrate complex (5Ryle M.J. Padmakumar R. Hausinger R.P. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 15278-15286Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). Secondly, x-ray structural analysis of several members of this enzyme family has demonstrated that substrate binding induces changes in the iron coordination sphere. The water molecule that occupies the sixth iron coordination site in the initial complex with AtsK, TauD, and factor-inducing hypoxia-inducible factor (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 7Elkins J.M. Ryle M.J. Clifton I.J. Dunning Hotopp J.C. Lloyd J.S. Burzlaff N.I. Baldwin J.E. Hausinger R.P. Roach P.L. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 5185-5192Crossref PubMed Scopus (192) Google Scholar, 8Elkins J.M. Hewitson K.S. McNeill L.A. Seibel J.F. Schlemminger I. Pugh C.W. Ratcliffe P.J. Schofield C.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 1802-1806Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (332) Google Scholar) is eliminated (or displaced in the case of clavaminate synthase, resulting in a longer metal-to-water distance (9Zhang Z.-H. Ren J. Stammers D.K. Baldwin J.E. Harlos K. Schofield C.J. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 127-133Crossref PubMed Scopus (252) Google Scholar)). It is believed that the change in the Fe(II) coordination environment induced by substrate binding within the active site pocket facilitates the binding of dioxygen. Nonetheless, this structural feature alone does not ensure protection against substrate-uncoupled oxidation of the enzyme. Decarboxylation of the cosubstrate αKG in the absence of substrate has long been known and leads to inactivation of the enzyme. The first reports of this phenomenon involved prolyl hydroxylase, the enzyme whose malfunction underlies scurvy (10Counts D.F. Cardinale G.J. Udenfield S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1978; 75: 2145-2149Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar, 11Rao N.V. Adams E. J. Biol. Chem. 1978; 253: 6327-6330Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 12Tuderman L. Myllyla ̈ R. Kivirikko K.I. Eur. J. Biochem. 1977; 80: 314-348Crossref Scopus (204) Google Scholar) in which the uncoupled turnover results in the metal becoming oxidized in an ascorbic acid-reversible manner (13Myllyla ̈ R. Majamaa K. Gu ̈nzler V. Hanauske-Abel H.N. Kivirikko K.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 5403-5405Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Similar ascorbate-reversible uncoupled reactions have been reported for several other enzymes in this family, and ascorbic acid is a widespread component in the buffers used to assay these enzymes to avoid rapid inactivation (1Kahnert A. Kertesz M.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 31661-31667Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Assuming that the same mechanism of cosubstrate oxidation occurs for the substrate-free complex as in the catalytic cycle, a highly reactive Fe(IV)=O-ferryl species would be formed concomitantly with αKG decarboxylation. As discussed in the case of deacetylcephalosporin synthase (14Valega ̊rd K. Terwisscha van Scheltinga A.C. Dubus A. Ranghino G. O ̈ster L.M. Hajdu J. Andersson I. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2003; 11: 95-101Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar), a second cosubstrate molecule could then coordinate to the active site and undergo oxidation in the absence of substrate. This would generate an Fe(III)-protein complex that could be transformed into an active species by ascorbate or other mild reducing agents. A different pathway, leading to irreversibly modified enzymes, has been reported for TfdA, AlkB, and TauD. During the uncoupled reaction of TauD, ∼60% of the inactivated complexes can be recovered by reduction, whereas approximately one-third of the molecules are transformed into a Fe(III)-succinate-catecholate species (15Ryle M.J. Koehntop K.D. Liu A. Que L. Hausinger R.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 3790-3795Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar) that are produced by enzyme self-hydroxylation at the side chain of Tyr73. For TfdA and AlkB, analogous hydroxylation of a tryptophan side chain has been observed (16Henshaw T.F. Feig M. Hausinger R.P. J. Inorg. Biochem. 2004; 98: 856-861Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar, 17Liu A. Ho R.Y.N. Que Jr., L. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2001; 123: 5126-5127Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar). The precise location of the relevant hydroxylated aromatic residue within the protein framework varies among enzymes. Hydroxylation of an aromatic side chain by the ferryl intermediate generated in the absence of proper substrate would constitute a definitive mechanism for enzyme inactivation and thus of self-protection in case of a lack of cosubstrate or another suitable reducing agent to mediate the reversible inactivation. Here we describe the crystal structures of the alkylsulfatase AtsK in complexes with succinate and water in the metal binding site as well as with succinate and Fe(II) (PDB entries 1VZ4 for succinate-Fe(II)·AtsK and 1VZ5 for succinate-AtsK). In the second structure, a tyrosine side chain coordinates to the iron via its hydroxyl group. This amino acid was part of a flexible loop in the crystal structures of AtsK previously described (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). This structure provides insight into the mechanism of the self-hydroxylation reaction similar to the one reported for TauD and TfdA. In addition, EPR measurements on the Fe(II)·αKG·AtsK complex and its reaction products upon exposure to oxygen were undertaken. The crystal structure of Fe·αKG·AtsK with and without substrate (PDB entries 1oii and 1oik) (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar) is compared with the succinate-AtsK complexes determined in this work, and the structural aspects of the self-hydroxylation mechanism are discussed. Crystallization—Crystals of the succinate-AtsK-complex were grown at 20 °C by hanging drop vapor diffusion. Crystals grew out of a mixture of equal volumes of protein and well solution (2 μl each) The protein solution contained 18 mg/ml of the apoform of AtsK and 20 mm Tris/HCl at pH 7.5. The well solution contained 25 mm ammonium sulfate, 175 mm sodium succinate, pH 5.6, 15% polyethylene glycol 4000, and 30% glycerol. Crystals grew to a typical size of 0.05 × 0.1 × 0.3 mm3 over 1–4 weeks and could be flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen without a further cryoprotectant. The crystals belong to the orthorhombic space group P212121. Iron was soaked into the succinate-AtsK-complex under anaerobic conditions. The crystals were transferred to an anaerobically prepared solution containing the additives of the mother liquor. A solution containing the mother liquor and 10 mm Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2·6H2O was added stepwise to the crystals to a total Fe2+ concentration of 2 mm. The crystals were incubated under anaerobic conditions for 36 h. The space group changed upon soaking from P212121 to I212121. Data Collection and Processing—X-ray diffraction data were collected at 100 K on beamline BL2 at the Protein Structure Factory c/o BESSY in Berlin using a MAR345 image plate detector to a resolution of 2.15 Å for the succinate-AtsK complex and of 2.5 Å for the succinate-Fe(II)·AtsK complex at a wavelength of 0.9000 and 0.8976 Å, respectively. Data were processed with the programs DENZO and SCALEPACK (18Otwinowski Z. Minor W. Methods Enzymol. 1997; 276: 307-326Crossref PubMed Scopus (38573) Google Scholar) and evaluated and prepared with the Bruker program XPREP. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D. 1997; 53: 240-255Crossref PubMed Scopus (13870) Google Scholar). Further refinement of the structures included non-crystallographic symmetry with tight restraints for the positional and thermal parameters of the main chain atoms and medium restraints for the side chain atoms. Because of non-crystallographic symmetry, the data for calculating the Rfree value were selected in thin resolution shells to prevent correlation between work and free sets of reflections. For the TLS refinement of the succinate-AtsK structure, each of the four monomers in the asymmetric unit was defined as a rigid body. TLS refinement of the Fe-succinate-AtsK complex did not improve the quality of the model as monitored by Rfree and was therefore abandoned. Water molecules were built in by XtalView (21McRee D.E. J. Struct. Biol. 1999; 125: 156-165Crossref PubMed Scopus (2022) Google Scholar), and their B-factors and stereochemistry were evaluated manually. The restraints for the succinate molecules were taken from the standard REFMAC5 library. In case of the Fe-succinate-AtsK complex, the presence of an iron atom in the iron binding site was confirmed by the observed bond lengths and the anomalous signal in a 3-Å in-house data set (λ = 1.54 Å) collected on the same crystal (anomalous signal to noise ratio of 1.4). Crystallogr. 1991; 24: 946-950Crossref Google Scholar) EPR Spectroscopy—EPR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ELEXSYS E500 X-band spectrometer equipped with the digital temperature control system ER 4131VT. Nitrogen was used as a coolant. The microwave power was selected within the range 2–10 milliwatts. A microwave frequency of around 9.44 GHz and the modulation amplitude of 4 G at a modulation frequency of 100 kHz were used for all of the measurements. The protein sample was prepared anaerobically under argon addition of 0.9 equivalents of Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2·6H2O and 5 mm α-ketoglutaric acid or 5 mm succinic acid, respectively, to 0.8 mm AtsK in 20 mm Tris, pH 7.5. The solution also contained 20% v/v glycerol. Oxygen exposure of the solution was performed by streaming O2 through the sample for 5 s. After incubation at room temperature for 20 s and 2, 5, 20, and 90 min, the sample was frozen in liquid nitrogen and the spectrum was recorded at 150 K. For comparison, an EPR spectrum was collected on an anaerobically prepared solution containing 0.75 mm Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2·6H2O and 5 mm α-ketoglutaric acid, 20% glycerol, and 20 mm Tris, pH 7.5, which was then exposed to oxygen. The spectrum of the anaerobic sample showed a small peak at g = 4.25 as a result of contamination of Fe(III) in the solution (26Munro O.Q. de Wet M. Pollak H. van Wyk J. Marques H.M. J. Chem. Soc. Faraday Trans. 1998; 94: 1743-1752Crossref Scopus (20) Google Scholar). This peak increased upon oxygen exposure. A peak with similar intensity appeared for the anaerobic protein sample, but it did not increase upon oxygen exposure of the protein sample. Instead, different features appeared in the spectrum. We know from previous AtsK handling that the Fe(III) that is present as an impurity in the Fe(II) stock solution does not bind to the protein (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). The structure of AtsK displays an α/β-domain that folds into a jelly roll motif with a β-sheet core flanked by α-helices characteristic for this enzyme family and a second α/β-domain (Fig. 2) (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). The core domain contains the active site made up of the iron binding, the cosubstrate binding, and the substrate binding sites. In the previously reported Fe·αKG·AtsK complex (PDB entry 1oii) (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), the iron is coordinated by the protein via His-108(Nϵ2), Asp-110(Oδ1), and His-264(Nϵ2) by the cosubstrate via its carbonyl-oxygen opposite to Asp110 and via one oxygen atom of its α-carboxyl group opposite to His108. The iron coordination sphere is completed by a water molecule opposite to His264. The cosubstrate binds to the protein through a salt bridge between its γ-carboxyl group and Arg-275(Nχ1 and Nχ2) assisted by a hydrogen bond from Thr-135(Oγ1) to this carboxyl group. Another hydrogen bond between the α-carboxyl oxygen atom not involved in iron binding and Arg-279(Nχ2) contributes to hold its position. In the Fe·αKG·substrate complex, the sulfate ester faces the metal center from the water binding site with the sulfate group forming hydrogen bonds to Val-111(N), Arg-279(Nχ2), and His-81(Nϵ2). The last of these residues forms part of a short disordered loop in the substrate-free structure. The water molecule is displaced from the iron, leaving a coordinatively unsaturated metal ion. Arg279 changes its side chain conformation upon substrate binding, thereby tightening the interaction with the cosubstrate molecule by forming a second hydrogen bond between the α-carboxyl group of αKG and Arg-279(Nϵ) (Fig. 3). Succinate Binds into the Cosubstrate Binding Site, Water Fills the Metal Binding Site, and His214 Adopts a Conformation That Closes the Substrate Binding Pocket—In the succinate-AtsK complex, a water molecule occupies the metal binding site, as indicated by its distances to the protein and the succinate molecule (Table III). The water molecule in the iron binding site forms hydrogen bonds with the succinate molecules, His-108(Nϵ2), Asp-110(Oδ1), and His-264(Nϵ2), the distortion imposed by the longer distances resulting in a pyramidal rather than tetrahedral coordination. In the corresponding iron-free αKG·AtsK structure (PDB entry 1oih) (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), this position is filled by a sodium cation. Alteration of the protonation state of the histidine side chains in the presence of succinate is presumably responsible for this difference. The succinate molecule is held in place by interactions with the same amino acids that coordinate αKG. One of its carboxyl groups forms salt bridges with Arg-275(Nχ1 and Nχ2) and a hydrogen bond with Thr-135(Oγ1). The other carboxyl group is oriented toward the metal binding site and interacts with Arg-279(Nχ2) as described for the non-iron-binding α-carboxyl oxygen atom of αKG. Thus, the orientation of the side chain of Arg279 is maintained relative to that found in the Fe·αKG·AtsK structure. Nevertheless, there is one significant conformational change between the two structures within the active site of the protein. His214 is oriented parallel to the side chain of His108 as described in the structure of the apoform of AtsK, although no direct contact with the succinate molecule was observed. In the Fe·αKG·AtsK structure, the side chain of His214 points away from His108. As shown by the structure of the Fe·αKG·AtsK·2-ethyl-1-hexyl sulfate ester complex (PDB entry 1oik) (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), this orientation provides a cleft for the aliphatic side chain of the substrate. On the contrary, the apostructure and the structure reported here show a closing of the substrate binding pocket. The binding site for the sulfate group of the substrate close to Val111 and Arg279 is occupied by a water molecule that hydrogen bonds to Val-111(N). This solvent molecule does not interact with Arg279 or His81 for which no electron density can be seen.Table IIISelected bond lengthsAtsK complexHis-108(Nϵ2)-H2O/FeAsp-110(Oδ1)-H2O/FeHis-264(Nϵ2)-H2O/FeSucc(O1)-FeTyr-168(Oχ)-FeÅSuccinate (PDB entry 1VZ5)2.742.583.192.602.862.993.622.642.432.362.612.512.782.933.562.49Succinate + Fe (PDB entry 1VZ4)2.162.052.171.962.302.292.011.992.082.17 Open table in a new tab The Presence of Iron and Succinate in the Active Site Induces Coordination of Tyr168 along with Major Conformational Changes—In crystals grown in the presence of succinate and soaked in an Fe(II) solution under anaerobic conditions, the water molecule in the metal binding site is replaced by an iron atom. The metal adopts a 5-fold coordination. Four of these ligands are made up by the AtsK iron-binding triad His-108(Nϵ2), Asp-110(Oδ1), and His-264(Nϵ2) and one of the succinate oxygen atoms. Unexpectedly and most interestingly, the fifth ligand is the side chain oxygen atom of Tyr-168(Oχ), which approaches from the substrate binding site to complete the coordination sphere. This tyrosine is part of a 25 amino acid long flexible loop between Glu165 and Tyr192 that is not visible in the electron density of any other structure of AtsK previously described (Fig. 4). Here, the amino acids Tyr166 to Ala169 are involved in a hydrogen bond network with the amino acids constituting the active site and thus adopt an ordered structure that is clearly visible in the electron density. The rearrangement of this part of the loop is accompanied by a structural change involving two strands in the β-sheet of the jelly roll core (Fig. 5). The side chain of Arg279, which has been suggested to play the role of a linker between the substrate and cosubstrate binding areas, changes its position and conformation. Besides binding the iron-coordinating carboxyl group of the succinate molecule, Arg-279(Nχ1) forms a hydrogen bond with Tyr-168(Oχ) (monomer A, 2.70 Å; monomer D, 2.92 Å). The Arg279 rearrangement is induced by the orientation of the succinate molecule close to the iron, shifting Arg279 closer toward the metal binding site than observed in the Fe·αKG or the iron-free succinate complex. A consequence of the reorientation of Arg279 is the breakage of the hydrogen bond to Thr-281(Oγ1) that is observed in all but the Fe·αKG·AtsK·2-ethyl-1-hexyl sulfate ester structure. The side chain of Thr281 changes its orientation and forms a hydrogen bond with Val79 (monomer A, 2.79 Å; monomer D, 3.07 Å). This hydrogen bond was also present in the substrate-AtsK structure. This new contact fixes the positions of Ala80 and His81, which are part of a formerly disordered loop between Val79 and Pro85. In the substrate-AtsK structure, His81 is involved in substrate binding and there it has been assumed to be important not only for substrate binding but also for capping the active site. In the structure described here, His-81(Nϵ2) forms a hydrogen bond with Asp-167(Oδ2) (monomer A, 3.03 Å; monomer D, 3.24 Å). The latter amino acid was part of the long flexible loop that could not be modeled in the AtsK-substrate complex. This hydrogen bond strengthens the fixation of the loop carrying Tyr168 and creates a lid over the active site. The interaction between Asp167 and His81 places the entire β-strand β4 closer to the active site, and the interaction between Val79 and Thr281 brings β-strand β16 closer to β4 and thus narrows the upper end of the jelly roll barrel (Table III). EPR Spectra Reveal an Fe(III) Low Spin Species after Oxygen Exposure—XAS measurement of the Fe(II)·αKG·AtsK complex under aerobic conditions showed that the iron is oxidized within the active site (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). This iron species was further investigated by EPR analysis. In TauD and TfdA, Fe(III) high spin complexes were observed as reaction products. The occurrence in TauD of only one signal at g = 4.3 for a rhombic high spin Fe(III) complex allowed a second signal at g = 2, which decreased over time, to be assigned to the tyrosine radical (27Ryle M.J. Liu A. Muthukumaran R.B. Ho R.Y.N. Koehntop K.D. McCracken J. Que Jr., L. Hausinger R.P. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 1854-1862Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). For TfdA, features at g-values of 7.4, 5.8, 4.3, and 2.0 were reported and interpreted as the result of Fe(III) high spin (S = 5/2) complex formation (17Liu A. Ho R.Y.N. Que Jr., L. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2001; 123: 5126-5127Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar). Oxygen exposure of the Fe(II)·αKG·AtsK complex leads to the development of an intense EPR feature at g = 2.15. A second peak at g = 4.27 is present prior to oxygen exposure and in a reference sample prepared in the absence of AtsK. In the latter sample, the intensity of this peak increases upon oxygen exposure, which is not observed in the presence of protein. The spectra were recorded after oxygen addition and incubation at room temperature for 20 s, 2, 5, 20, and 90 min. The peak at g = 2.15 appears after 2 min and with increasing incubation time, a significant shift of this signal toward lower field is observed (g = 2.24 after 90 min). In addition, much weaker signals are observed at g = 1.9 and 1.75, whose intensity increases between 2 and 20 min of incubation, and almost disappear after 90 min of incubation. These signals indicate the presence of a low spin Fe(III) (S = 1/2) species. The altered electronic features of the Fe(III) ion revealed by the shift of the EPR signal could be the result of a rearrangement in the coordination sphere of the metal ion during the uncoupled oxidation. The width of the signal did not allow us to resolve further signals around g = 2 and thus assign a putative tyrosine radical signal. Ryle et al. (15Ryle M.J. Koehntop K.D. Liu A. Que L. Hausinger R.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 3790-3795Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar) reported on the oxidation of the iron center in an Fe(II)-succinate-TauD complex in the presence of oxygen monitored by UV-visible and Raman spectroscopy (15Ryle M.J. Koehntop K.D. Liu A. Que L. Hausinger R.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 3790-3795Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). The reaction of the iron center with molecular oxygen occurred over a period of hours rather than minutes as seen for the Fe(II)·αKG·TauD complex. Therefore, we investigated the EPR features of the Fe(II)-succinate-AtsK complex upon oxygen exposure. In agreement with the TauD results, we did not find a change in the EPR spectrum of the Fe(II)-succinate-AtsK sample after oxygen exposure and incubation for 5 min. The complex could not be studied after longer incubation at room temperature as the protein slowly precipitated. This reduced reactivity of the iron is consistent with the formation of a less accessible metal center in the succinate complex, as formerly disordered loops form the lid over the active site that is seen in the crystal structure of AtsK. The crystallographic studies on the succinate complexes of AtsK show that the presence of succinate and iron (II) in the active site of AtsK causes the coordination of a tyrosine side chain to the iron center. The penta-coordinated iron complex seen in the crystals differs from the real mechanistic intermediate, since it has not been derived from a reaction taking place at the active site between aKG and dioxygen, which would result in a hexa-coordinated metal center in a higher oxidation state. Nevertheless, it mimics the structural response of the enzyme to the presence of succinate in the absence of either substrate or product. Although not directly involved in cosubstrate oxidation, the presence of a substrate molecule in the active site facilitates the coordination of dioxygen to the iron atom, concomitant with the coordination of the substrate to its binding site. A water molecule is removed from the iron coordination sphere to leave a 5-fold coordinated iron center and a potential oxygen binding site. By decarboxylating the αKG, the iron center is transformed into an Fe(IV)=O species (27Ryle M.J. Liu A. Muthukumaran R.B. Ho R.Y.N. Koehntop K.D. McCracken J. Que Jr., L. Hausinger R.P. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 1854-1862Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar) and the substrate molecule reacts with this Fe(IV)=O intermediate in the next step. In the absence of substrate, e.g. in the Fe·αKG·AtsK complex, the water molecule remains bound to the iron. This does not mean that it cannot be replaced by an approaching dioxygen molecule; however, if this replacement occurs, the activation energy required should be substantially higher than when the substrate is bound, in agreement with the much longer reaction time of the substrate-free complex with oxygen in respect to the substrate complex (15Ryle M.J. Koehntop K.D. Liu A. Que L. Hausinger R.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 3790-3795Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). EPR measurements provide clear evidence for a reaction between the Fe(II)·αKG·AtsK complex and oxygen in the absence of substrate, e.g. an oxidation uncoupled from substrate binding. In light of these results and the self-hydroxylation reaction reported for TauD (15Ryle M.J. Koehntop K.D. Liu A. Que L. Hausinger R.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 3790-3795Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar), we propose a similar self-protection mechanism for the αKG-dependent dioxygenase AtsK. The structural information obtained from the succinate complexes of AtsK provides a view of how this self-hydroxylation of an aromatic residue is accomplished. Building on the pathway of the catalytic reaction (Fig. 1), we assume that dioxygen coordinates to the active site in an initial step of the uncoupled mechanism and that the cosubstrate is then oxidized and split into succinate and carbon dioxide. This leaves an activated ferryl species that needs to be quenched since it is capable of initiating undesired radical side reactions. Therefore, in this model, the conversion of the αKG into succinate in absence of substrate is the trigger for the tyrosine approach. The Fe-succinate-AtsK structure now gives insight into how the tyrosine side chain is recruited to the active site. The rearrangement of the Arg279 side chain, induced by the replacement of αKG into succinate, leads to a cascade of hydrogen bond reorganization. When there is no substrate bound to the protein, the flexible loop between 165 and 191 can dock at the open end of the active site via interaction between Asp167 and His81 and between Tyr168 and Arg279. This corroborates the previous hypothesis (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar) that Arg279 plays the role of a linker between the cosubstrate and the substrate binding site. The coordinative binding of the tyrosine side chain to the ferryl species would have the double effect of shielding other alternative oxidation targets by closing the active site pocket and of placing a tyrosine carbon atom ortho to the hydroxyl group at an appropriate distance to react with the ferryl species and form a radical intermediate. The conversion into a catecholate would be the final step of enzyme self-hydroxylation. Whether the oxygen atom of the hydroxyl radical transferred to the tyrosine radical originates from dioxygen or from a water molecule cannot be determined from the crystal structure. The water molecule as a source seems to be more likely by comparison with TauD for which the catecholate oxygen atom is incorporated from the solvent (15Ryle M.J. Koehntop K.D. Liu A. Que L. Hausinger R.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 3790-3795Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar, 27Ryle M.J. Liu A. Muthukumaran R.B. Ho R.Y.N. Koehntop K.D. McCracken J. Que Jr., L. Hausinger R.P. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 1854-1862Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). For TauD and other enzymes, it has been shown that the modified enzyme is irreversibly inactivated, which implies the formation of a stable catecholate complex and a permanently closed active site. These results do not contradict the finding that only approximately one-third of the protein undergoes self-hydroxylation in the presence of oxygen but in the absence of substrate. In the case of deacetylcephalosporin synthase, it has been suggested by Valegård et al. (14Valega ̊rd K. Terwisscha van Scheltinga A.C. Dubus A. Ranghino G. O ̈ster L.M. Hajdu J. Andersson I. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2003; 11: 95-101Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar) that a second cosubstrate molecule could coordinate to the substrate binding site and undergo oxidation in the uncoupled reaction. In this case, an αKG molecule would occupy this site and the tyrosine molecule could not approach and coordinate to the iron. The tyrosine side chain that had been shown to be the target of self-hydroxylation in TauD is Tyr73. In terms of sequence, it is not related to Tyr168 of AtsK. Crystal structures of TauD are available for substrate complexes or the apoform of the protein (7Elkins J.M. Ryle M.J. Clifton I.J. Dunning Hotopp J.C. Lloyd J.S. Burzlaff N.I. Baldwin J.E. Hausinger R.P. Roach P.L. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 5185-5192Crossref PubMed Scopus (192) Google Scholar, 28O'Brien J.R. Schuller D.J. Yang V.S. Dillard B.D. Lanzilotta W.N. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 5547-5554Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar), and both show that Tyr73 is part of the substrate binding site. Tyr73 belongs to a short loop related to the loop between Val79 and Pro85 in AtsK, which itself does not contain any aromatic amino acids. The structural relationship between Tyr-168(AtsK) and Tyr-73(TauD) supports the assumption that Tyr168 undergoes hydroxylation in the uncoupled oxidation of AtsK. In conclusion, we propose an enzyme self-hydroxylation pathway as an irreversible self-inactivation process for the αKG-dependent dioxygenase AtsK and describe a putative cascade of protein rearrangements following cosubstrate decarboxylation in the absence of a substrate molecule. The side chain of Tyr168 that coordinates to the metal ion in the Fe-succinate-AtsK structure most probably undergoes oxidation to yield a catecholate species. In an attempt to structurally characterize the reaction product of the uncoupled oxidation, we took crystals that had been grown in the presence of αKG and soaked anaerobically in Fe(II) (6Mu ̈ller I. Kahnert A. Pape T. Sheldrick G.M. Meyer-Klauke W. Dierks T. Kertesz M. Uso ́n I. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 3075-3088Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar) and exposed them to oxygen. During oxygen exposure, the colorless crystals became yellow, indicating the formation of iron(III). This change in color was accompanied by a change in the symmetry: The anaerobic form had the space group P212121, and upon oxygen exposure, it changed to I212121. The crystals diffracted to a resolution of 2.3 Å, but the difference electron density close to the iron binding site could not be interpreted (data not shown). This may arise from a disorder among different reaction products from 1) competing reactions because αKG, which may lead to reversible inactivation, is present in large excess, 2) incomplete reaction, and 3) limitation in the quality of the experimental data. Therefore, further work on this structure is under way. We are grateful to George M. Sheldrick for scientific discussion and support. We thank Tewes Tralau for technical assistance. Data collection at the synchrotron beamline BL2 in Berlin at the PSF c/o BESSY and assistance from Uwe Müller are gratefully acknowledged.

GABA functions as an inhibitory neurotransmitter in body muscles and as an excitatory neurotransmitter in enteric muscles in Caenorhabditis elegans. Whereas many of the components of the GABA-ergic neurotransmission in this organism have been identified at the molecular and functional levels, no transporter specific for this neurotransmitter has been identified to date. Here we report on the cloning and functional characterization of a GABA transporter from C. elegans (ceGAT-1) and on the functional relevance of the transporter to the biology of body muscles and enteric muscles. ceGAT-1 is coded by snf-11 gene, a member of the sodium-dependent neurotransmitter symporter gene family in C. elegans. The cloned ceGAT-1 functions as a Na+/Cl–-coupled high-affinity transporter selective for GABA with a Kt of ∼15 μm. The Na+:Cl–:GABA stoichiometry for ceGAT-1-mediated transport process is 2:1:1. The transport process is electrogenic as evidenced from GABA-induced inward currents in Xenopus laevis oocytes that express ceGAT-1 heterologously. The transporter is expressed exclusively in GABA-ergic neurons and in two other additional neurons. We also investigated the functional relevance of ceGAT-1 to the biology of body muscles and enteric muscles by ceGAT-1-specific RNA interference (RNAi) in rrf-3 mutant, a strain of C. elegans in which neurons are not refractory to RNAi as in the wild type strain. The down-regulation of ceGAT-1 by RNAi leads to an interesting phenotype associated with altered function of body muscles (as evident from changes in thrashing frequency) and enteric muscles (as evident from the rates of defecation failure) and also with altered sensitivity to aldicarb-induced paralysis. These findings provide unequivocal evidence for a modulatory role of GABA and ceGAT-1 in the biology of cholinergic neurons and in the function of body muscles and enteric muscles in this organism. Whereas many of the components of the GABA-ergic neurotransmission in this organism have been identified at the molecular and functional levels, no transporter specific for this neurotransmitter has been identified to date. The cloned ceGAT-1 functions as a Na+/Cl–-coupled high-affinity transporter selective for GABA with a Kt of ∼15 μm. The Na+:Cl–:GABA stoichiometry for ceGAT-1-mediated transport process is 2:1:1. The transport process is electrogenic as evidenced from GABA-induced inward currents in Xenopus laevis oocytes that express ceGAT-1 heterologously. The transporter is expressed exclusively in GABA-ergic neurons and in two other additional neurons. We also investigated the functional relevance of ceGAT-1 to the biology of body muscles and enteric muscles by ceGAT-1-specific RNA interference (RNAi) in rrf-3 mutant, a strain of C. elegans in which neurons are not refractory to RNAi as in the wild type strain. The down-regulation of ceGAT-1 by RNAi leads to an interesting phenotype associated with altered function of body muscles (as evident from changes in thrashing frequency) and enteric muscles (as evident from the rates of defecation failure) and also with altered sensitivity to aldicarb-induced paralysis. These findings provide unequivocal evidence for a modulatory role of GABA and ceGAT-1 in the biology of cholinergic neurons and in the function of body muscles and enteric muscles in this organism. γ-Aminobutyric acid (GABA) 1The abbreviations used are: GABA, γ-aminobutyric acid; ceGAT-1, C. elegans GABA transporter-1; RNAi, RNA interference; RT, reverse transcription; GFP, green fluorescent protein; HRPE, human retinal pigment epithelial; NMDG, N-methyl-d-glucamine; dsRNA, double-stranded RNA; cRNA, complementary RNA; snf, sodium-dependent neurotransmitter symporter family; BGT, betaine/GABA transporter; unc, uncoordinated. is the most abundant inhibitory neurotransmitter in vertebrates and invertebrates. GABAergic neurotransmission is used clinically as the target of antiepileptic, anxiolytic, and antispasmodic drugs (1Bowery N.G. Nistico G. GABA, Basic Research and Clinical Applications. Pythagora, Rome, Italy1989: 1-426Google Scholar, 2Brambilla P. Perez J. Barale F. Schettini G. Soares J.C. Mol. Psychiatry. 2003; 8: 721-737Crossref PubMed Scopus (231) Google Scholar, 3Lydiard R.B. J. Clin. Psychiatry. 2003; 64: 21-27PubMed Google Scholar, 4Ashton H. Young A.H. J. Psychopharmacol. 2003; 17: 174-178Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 5Sarup A. Larsson O.M. Schousboe A. Curr. Drug Targets CNS Neurol. Disord. 2003; 2: 269-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). Several molecular components are involved in GABA-ergic neurotransmission. These include glutamic acid decarboxylase (the enzyme needed for the production of GABA from glutamate), vesicular GABA transporter (the transporter in presynaptic neurons that transports GABA into synaptic vesicles), GABA receptors (the receptors present on the postsynaptic membrane to transmit the GABAergic signals), and GABA transporters (the transporters present in presynaptic neurons and glial cells that participate in the clearance of GABA from the synapse). Mammals, including humans, express four different GABA transporters (GATs) of which only two are present specifically in GABA-ergic neurons. These are GAT-1 and GAT-3 (6Dalby N.O. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 2003; 479: 127-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 7Chen N.H. Reith M.E.A. Quick M.W. Pfluegers Arch. Eur. J. Physiol. 2004; 447: 519-531Crossref PubMed Scopus (341) Google Scholar). GAT-1 is the predominant GABA transporter in the brain, co-localizes with markers of GABAergic neurons, and is expressed in the axons and presynaptic membranes (8Radian R. Ottersen O.P. Storm-Mathisen J. Castel M. Kanner B.I. J. Neurosci. 1990; 10: 1319-1330Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Minelli A. Brecha N.C. Karschin C. DeBiasi S. Conti F. J. Neurosci. 1995; 15: 7734-7746Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 10Ikegaki N. Saito N. Hashima M. Tanaka C. Brain Res. Mol. Brain Res. 1994; 26: 47-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar). GAT-3 is also expressed exclusively in the brain where it is found in GABA-ergic nerve terminals as well as in glial cells (11Minelli A. DeBiasi S. Brecha N.C. Zuccarello L.V. Conti F. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 6255-6264Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 12DeBiasi S. Vitellaro-Zuccarello L. Brecha N.C. Neuroscience. 1998; 83: 815-828Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). The other two GABA transporters (GAT-2 and BGT-1/GAT-4, also known as betaine/GABA transporter) are not related to GABA-ergic neurotransmission. Antiepileptic, anxiolytic, and antispasmodic drugs produce their therapeutic effects by enhancing GABAergic neurotransmission (1Bowery N.G. Nistico G. GABA, Basic Research and Clinical Applications. Pythagora, Rome, Italy1989: 1-426Google Scholar, 2Brambilla P. Perez J. Barale F. Schettini G. Soares J.C. Mol. Psychiatry. 2003; 8: 721-737Crossref PubMed Scopus (231) Google Scholar, 3Lydiard R.B. J. Clin. Psychiatry. 2003; 64: 21-27PubMed Google Scholar, 4Ashton H. Young A.H. J. Psychopharmacol. 2003; 17: 174-178Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 5Sarup A. Larsson O.M. Schousboe A. Curr. Drug Targets CNS Neurol. Disord. 2003; 2: 269-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). The activation of GABAergic neurotransmission can be accomplished by drugs that function either as agonists of GABA receptors or inhibitors of GABA transporters. The latter class of drugs such as tiagabine (an antiepileptic drug) increases the levels of GABA in the synaptic cleft by their ability to block the clearance of the neurotransmitter from the synapse via GABA transporters and thus enhances GABA-ergic neurotransmission (5Sarup A. Larsson O.M. Schousboe A. Curr. Drug Targets CNS Neurol. Disord. 2003; 2: 269-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). Even though GAT-1 and GAT-3 have been identified at the molecular level more than a decade ago and are known to be linked to diseases such as epilepsy and schizophrenia (6Dalby N.O. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 2003; 479: 127-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 7Chen N.H. Reith M.E.A. Quick M.W. Pfluegers Arch. Eur. J. Physiol. 2004; 447: 519-531Crossref PubMed Scopus (341) Google Scholar), there are no knock-out animal models reported in the literature describing the phenotypic changes that occur as a consequence of specific deletion of either GAT-1 or GAT-3. GABA-ergic neurotransmission plays a critical role in the function of body muscles and enteric muscles in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans (13Schuske K. Beg A.A. Jorgensen E.M. Trends Neurosci. 2004; 27: 407-414Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). There are 26 GABA-ergic neurons in this organism as identified by immunocytochemistry using a polyclonal antibody specific for GABA (14McIntire S.L. Jorgensen E. Kaplan J. Horvitz H.R. Nature. 1993; 364: 337-341Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). These consist of the 6 DD neurons, 13 VD neurons, 4 RME neurons, 1 AVL neuron, 1 DVB neuron, and 1 RIS neuron. The connectivity of all of these neurons that use GABA as the neurotransmitter has been well established (14McIntire S.L. Jorgensen E. Kaplan J. Horvitz H.R. Nature. 1993; 364: 337-341Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). The DD and VD neurons control the function of body muscles that are involved in locomotion. The RME neurons innervate the muscle in the head that participates in foraging. The AVL and DVB neurons control the function of enteric muscles that participate, together with body muscles, in the defecation cycle. The function of the RIS neuron is not well understood. The molecular components of GABAergic neurotransmission in C. elegans are similar to those in mammals. These include glutamic acid decarboxylase (known as unc-25), vesicular GABA transporter (known as unc-47), and a GABA receptor (known as unc-49) (13Schuske K. Beg A.A. Jorgensen E.M. Trends Neurosci. 2004; 27: 407-414Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar, 15McIntire S.L. Jorgensen E. Horvitz H.R. Nature. 1993; 364: 334-337Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar). Two other proteins have also been shown to be essential for normal GABAergic neurotransmission in C. elegans (i.e. unc-30 that participates in the differentiation of GABA-ergic neurons and unc-46 that is essential for synaptic release of GABA) (13Schuske K. Beg A.A. Jorgensen E.M. Trends Neurosci. 2004; 27: 407-414Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar, 15McIntire S.L. Jorgensen E. Horvitz H.R. Nature. 1993; 364: 334-337Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar). unc-25, unc-30, unc-46, unc-47, and unc-49 are members of the uncoordinated gene class. All of the members of this gene class, when made nonfunctional, lead to a loss of coordination of muscle function in the organism. The C. elegans counterpart(s) of mammalian GABA transporters has/have not yet been identified at the molecular level. GABA transporters in mammals belong to the SLC6 gene family, which consists of at least 19 members (7Chen N.H. Reith M.E.A. Quick M.W. Pfluegers Arch. Eur. J. Physiol. 2004; 447: 519-531Crossref PubMed Scopus (341) Google Scholar). Most of the transporters in this gene family recognize neurotransmitters/neuromodulators (e.g. GABA, serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine, glycine, proline, and taurine) as substrates and are energetically coupled to the transmembrane gradients of Na+ and Cl–. Therefore, this family is called Na+/Cl–-dependent neurotransmitter transporter gene family. C. elegans also contains a sodium-dependent neurotransmitter symporter family (snf). A search in the WormBase (Release WS93 at www.wormbase.org) using the mammalian GABA transporter protein sequence as a query has revealed that there are 14 members in this snf gene family (snf-1, snf-2, and so forth) in the worm genome. Only two of them have so far been identified at the functional level. dat-1 (T23G5.5) encodes a dopamine transporter (16Jayanthi L.D. Apparsundaram S. Malone M.D. Ward E. Miller D.M. Eppler M. Blakely R.D. Mol. Pharmacol. 1998; 54: 601-609PubMed Google Scholar) and mod-5 (Y54E10BR.7) encodes a serotonin transporter (17Ranganathan R. Sawin E.R. Trent C. Horvitz H.R. J. Neurosci. 2001; 21: 5871-5884Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Recently, we undertook a study to identify the taurine transporter in C. elegans. When we searched the data base for the snf gene family with the mammalian taurine transporter as a query to identify the most likely candidate for the C. elegans taurine transporter, the search yielded snf-11 as the likely candidate based on amino acid sequence. Therefore, we isolated a full-length snf-11 cDNA clone from a C. elegans cDNA library and characterized its transport function, hoping that this clone would function as a Na+/Cl–-coupled transporter for taurine. Quite unexpectedly, these studies showed that snf-11 is not a taurine transporter but a GABA transporter. This represents the first GABA transporter to be identified at the functional level in C. elegans. In this paper, we describe the structural and functional aspects of this GABA transporter (ceGAT-1). In addition, we show here that ceGAT-1 is expressed in all of the GABA-ergic neurons (plus in two non-GABAergic neurons) and that down-regulation of GAT-1 expression by gene-specific RNA interference (RNAi) leads to changes in the function of body muscles and enteric muscles. Furthermore, RNAi-induced down-regulation of GAT-1 also leads to an interesting pharmacologic phenotype with altered cholinergic neurotransmission as evident from enhanced sensitivity to aldicarb (an inhibitor of acetylcholineesterase)-induced paralysis. To our knowledge, this represents the first report on the consequences of down-regulation of a GABA transporter in an animal model. Materials—[3H]GABA (specific radioactivity, 70 Ci/mmol) was purchased from PerkinElmer Life Sciences. The human retinal pigment epithelial (HRPE) cell line, used routinely in our laboratory for heterologous expression of cloned transporters, was maintained in Dulbecco's minimum essential medium/F-12 medium (1:1) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100 μg/ml streptomycin. Lipofectin was purchased from Invitrogen. Restriction enzymes were obtained from New England Biolabs (Beverly, MA). Magna nylon transfer membranes used in library screening were purchased from Micron Separations (Westboro, MA). Unlabeled GABA and its analogs and other amino acids were obtained from Sigma. A wild type nematode strain, C. elegans N2 (Bristol) and all of the other C. elegans mutant strains such as rrf-3 (NL-2099), unc-25 (e156), unc-47 (e307), and unc-2 (e55) were obtained from the Caenorhabditis Genetics Center (St. Paul, MN). Nematode Culture and RNA Preparation—Nematode culture was carried out using a standard procedure with a large-scale liquid cultivation protocol (18Lewis J.A. Fleming J.T. Methods Cell Biol. 1995; 48: 3-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (506) Google Scholar). The nematodes were cleaned by sedimentation through 15% (w/v) Ficoll 400 in 0.1 m NaCl. The pellet was then used for total RNA preparation. Total RNA was isolated using the TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen). Poly(A)+ mRNA was purified by affinity chromatography using oligo(dT)-cellulose. Reverse Transcription (RT)-PCR and Hybridization Probe Preparation—Our original aim was to clone the C. elegans taurine transporter. A search in the WormBase using the mammalian taurine transporter protein sequences as queries revealed that the gene T03F7.1 (GenBank™ accession number Z74041) located on chromosome V encodes a candidate plasma membrane transporter that may function as the sodium/chloride-coupled taurine transporter. Therefore, a pair of PCR primers specific for this gene was designed based on the sequence of the cosmid T03F7.1, 5′-GCA CTT TTC CTT CTT CTC GTC-3′ (forward primer) and 5′-GCA AAA ACC CAG CAA AAC TTC-3′ (reverse primer). These primers yielded a single DNA fragment in RT-PCR using the total RNA isolated from C. elegans as the template in the reaction. The size of the product was ∼0.9 kb, which agreed with the predicted size based on the distance between the two primers in the theoretically derived gene transcript. The RT-PCR product was gel-purified and subcloned into pGEM-Teasy vector (Promega Madison, WI). The molecular identity of the insert was established by DNA sequencing. This cDNA fragment was used as a probe to screen a C. elegans cDNA library. Construction of a Directional C. elegans cDNA Library—SuperScript plasmid system from Invitrogen was used to establish the cDNA library using the poly(A)+ RNA from C. elegans. The transformation of the ligated cDNA into Escherichia coli was performed by electroporation using ElectroMAX DH10B-competent cells. The bacteria plating, the filter lifting, the DNA fragment labeling, and the hybridization methods followed the routine procedure (19Fei Y.J. Fujita T. Lapp D.F. Ganapathy V. Leibach F.H. Biochem. J. 1998; 332: 565-572Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 20Fei Y.J. Romero M.F. Krause M. Liu J.C. Huang W. Ganapathy V. Leibach F.H. J. Biol. Acta. 1999; 1418: 239-244Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar, 24George R.L. Wu X. Huang W. Fei Y.J. Leibach F.H. Ganapathy V. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1999; 291: 596-603PubMed Google Scholar). HRPE cells grown in 24-well plates were infected with a recombinant vaccinia virus (VTF7–3) at a multiplicity of 10 plaque-forming units/cell. This virus carries the gene for T7 RNA polymerase in its genome. The virus was allowed to adsorb onto the cells for 30 min at 37 °C with gentle shaking of the plate. Cells were then transfected with the plasmid DNA (empty vector pSPORT or ceGAT-1 cDNA construct) using the lipofection procedure (Invitrogen). The cells were incubated at 37 °C for 12 h and then used for the determination of transport activity. The uptake of [3H]GABA was determined at 37 °C. In most experiments, the uptake medium was 25 mm Hepes/Tris, pH 7.5, containing 140 mm NaCl, 5.4 mm KCl, 1.8 mm CaCl2, 0.8 mm MgSO4, and 5 mm glucose. In experiments in which the cation and anion dependence of the transport process was investigated, NaCl was replaced isosmotically by sodium gluconate or N-methyl-d-glucamine (NMDG) chloride. Uptake measurements were routinely made in parallel in control cells transfected with the empty vector alone and in cells transfected with the vector-cDNA construct. The uptake activity in cDNA-transfected cells was adjusted for the endogenous activity measured in control cells to calculate the cDNA-specific activity. Experiments were performed in triplicate, and each experiment was repeated at least three times. Results are presented as means ± S.E. Assay of Aldicarb-induced Paralysis—This was done according to the procedure described by Mathews et al. (30Mathews E.A. Garcia E. Santi C.M. Mullen G.P. Thacker C. Moerman D.G. Snutch T.P. J. Neurosci. 2003; 23: 6537-6545Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Control and experimental (RNAi) worms (N2 and rrf-3 strains) (20–25 worms/experiment) were exposed to 0.5 mm aldicarb. Paralyzed worms were identified by a lack of response in terms of movement upon poking with a metal wire. The number of paralyzed worms was counted at different time periods following exposure to aldicarb. The experiment was repeated three times, and the data were analyzed as the percent of animals that were paralyzed at each time point. In the experiment in which the relevance of the abolition of GABA-ergic neurotransmission to aldicarb-induced paralysis was investigated using mutant strains, the worms (control strain N2 and the mutant strains unc-25, unc-47, and unc-2) were exposed to 0.5 mm aldicarb without the bacteria-mediated RNAi and the percent of paralyzed worms was determined at different time points following the exposure to aldicarb. This experiment was repeated twice. Thrashing Assay—This assay was used to investigate the frequency of contraction of body muscles in worms subjected to RNAi. These experiments were done using the RNAi-hypersensitive rrf-3 strain. Control and experimental (RNAi) worms were synchronously grown to the L4 stage. Individual worms

P-glycoprotein (P-gp, ABCB1) actively transports a broad range of cytotoxic compounds out of the cell. The COOH terminus of P-gp contains a dileucine motif (Leu1260-Leu1261) and a conserved phenylalanine (Phe1268). Similar residues in SUR1 (ABCC8) were reported to be important plasma membrane-targeting signals (Sharma, N., Crane, A., Clement, J. P. t., Gonzalez, G., Babenko, A. P., Bryan, J., and Aguilar-Bryan, L. (1999) J. Biol. Chem. 274, 20628–20632). Here, we used alanine-scanning mutagenesis to test whether these residues were essential for trafficking of P-gp to the cell surface. Mutant L1260A expressed a 150-kDa immature protein that did not reach the cell surface and was sensitive to digestion by Endo Hf. By contrast, mutants L1261A, F1268A, and wild-type P-gps expressed the 170-kDa mature proteins at the cell surface. Mutation of Leu1260 to Gly, Ile, Trp, Lys, or Glu also resulted in the expression of the 150-kDa immature protein. All of the mutants, however, expressed the 170-kDa protein in the presence of the drug substrate/specific chemical chaperone cyclosporin A. Mutant L1260A P-gp exhibited drug-stimulated ATPase activities similar to that of wild-type enzyme after rescue with cyclosporin A. Deletion of the last 22 amino acids (Q1259-Q1280) also caused misprocessing. The mutant, however, was rescued by expression in the presence of cyclosporin A and conferred resistance to colchicine in transfected cells. These results show that the dileucine motif is not a plasma membrane targeting signal. The COOH terminus is required for proper folding of P-gp but not for activity. P., Bryan, J., and Aguilar-Bryan, L. (1999) J. Biol. Chem. 274, 20628–20632). Here, we used alanine-scanning mutagenesis to test whether these residues were essential for trafficking of P-gp to the cell surface. Mutant L1260A expressed a 150-kDa immature protein that did not reach the cell surface and was sensitive to digestion by Endo Hf.
